title: Graphical Analysis Second Deriv Avg Rate of Change

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The continuous function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has domain <math alttext="negative 4 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, consisting of two line segments and a semicircle, is shown in the figure above. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a horizontal tangent at <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 0 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 4 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 4 is less than x, is less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The continuous function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has domain <math alttext="negative 4 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, consisting of two line segments and a semicircle, is shown in the figure above. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a horizontal tangent at <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 0 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 4 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 4 is less than x, is less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Classify each critical point from part (a) as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither for <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify each of your answers.

(c) For <math alttext="negative 4 less than x, less than 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, on what open intervals is <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing and concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Find the value of <math alttext="h of negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) Find the value of <math alttext="h of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Find the value of <math alttext="h double prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, or explain why it does not exist.

(g) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="negative 4 less than k, less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>k</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="h prime of k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="negative 4 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(h) Find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches negative 2, of, the fraction with numerator h prime of x, and denominator 3 x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(i) The function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="r of x equals, h of, open parenthesis, negative 3 x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="r prime of negative 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

topic.text: 1.5: Determining Limits Using Algebraic Properties of Limits

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
